True, kindergartners can't say "crayon", but they also can't say "grandfather" or "grandmother" and often shorten those to "grampa", "gramma", "papa" or "nana".
They also can't say "pacifier", which is where words like "binky" come from.
Basically what I'm getting at is using kindergartners as your baseline for pronunciation of words is wrong in every way. They mispronounce and shorten difficult words all the time, so them saying "cran" instead of "crayon" is as wrong as it is unsurprising.

For the people wondering Webster's Dictionary states the proper way to pronounce Crayon is in two syllables: krA on. The news station, 40/29 News, suggests the pronunciation “cran” may be from the Midwest, with commentators from Wisconsin, Chicago and St. Louis declaring they say the word that way.

To all of you saying "OH NATES RIGHT ITS CRAY-ON" or "CALI IS RIGHT ITS CRAN", or the other way you pronounce it... There is no right or wrong way to say it really.. It depends on your accent, because people with certain accents, tend to say things differently then others.
Take a look at Wednesday. Most people pronounce it like "Wensday". Same with February. Most people would say it like "Febuary".
It all just depends on what you were taught, and what you prefer to say. Some canadians say "crowns", some people say "crayns", some say "Cray-ons", and some say crans.
Its all opinion based, really. While there is a common way to say it, everyone is different and will say things in their own way.

Metals, well transitional metals can be vibrant colors. It depends on how many electron orbitals are open and when electron orbitals are available, light can be absorbed. As a result on the color wheel, it is the type of light that is absorbed (opposite). When electron orbitals are full, there can be no energy change. As a result, no light is absorbed. Which results in a colorless metal. Metals can't be dyed by crayons unfortunately. It is based off of electron in transitional metals. The word Crayon is tricky because it's the difference between visual learners and audio learners. People who learn words by listening (small children) hear "Cray-'ns". People who learn words by reading them will go with "Cray-Awns". The internet and YouTube specifically are full of visual learners. They enjoy YouTube because they are visual learners. So they are mostly going to fall into the Cray-Awns camp.
